3: Hey! Watanabe-San is back!
I'm back, too! And the food!
Cheers erupt among the Forsaken as they help Zong unload the food and settle into the wrapping process.
Looks interesting, Commandant. Could Liv and I try our hand at wrapping one?
You coming, Lee?
No, you go on ahead...
Halfway there, Lucia turns back, hesitant.
Commandant... if I manage to make a Zong, would you try one?
I see... I'm not that good at cooking, anyway...
Really? Okay, I'll give it a try.
We used to wrap Zongs together on the Nighter, from time to time.
Not many good memories on that ship, but a few do come by every once in a while.
True. No matter how dark our world gets, there are always a few things that shine bright.
Changyu bites into a steamed Zong, and his face turns.
Hey, you! Forsaken! Care to explain why this Zong is sweet?
What are you on about? Zongs are made to be sweet.
Zongs are supposed to be savory, with meat in the filling! This is a dessert!
Hey, kid! You got a problem with our Zongs, you come talk to Zong!
Spirited disagreement on the nature of Zongs notwithstanding, the bond between Changyu and the Forsaken seems to be stronger than ever.
You tell them, Commandant!
We've finishing wrapping ours too, Commandant. Please have a taste.
— A few days later, on board the Eternal Engine, Changyu debriefs Jamilah on recent events.
Sure wasn't easy, but at least we closed the Forsaken deal.
So these are the fabled Zongs of the Forsaken? Not bad. Easy to manufacture, and at a reasonable cost.
Slightly sweet. Not bad.
Maybe we can host a festival like Duanwu on the train... or better yet, promote it everywhere along our route.
Such a festival would involve every rung of society, encourage spending... there's money to be made here.
That's a swell idea, Boss, but I do disagree on one point.
Oh? Enlighten me.
Zongs are supposed to be savory, not sweet!
